title: Good Company: Tupperware Goes After Plastic and Food Waste
text:
Text size

Tupperware Brand Corp.’s classic reusable food containers have allowed consumers to lighten their environmental footprint for 70 years. Although made of plastic, the containers are sturdy and can be used over and over—eliminating the need for single-use plastics, while preventing food from going to waste in the fridge.

But this long-time U.S. brand (with a global business) is taking its sustainability efforts up several notches now through an ambitious, comprehensive program rolled out in April called “No Time to Waste.” Tupperware’s goal is to eventually eliminate waste throughout its manufacturing and distribution systems, as well as helping consumers to reduce their own waste.

“Tupperware products have been designed very intentionally to be extremely durable and to prevent food from spoiling—these are two things that around the world we are known for,” says Asha Gupta, chief strategy and marketing officer at Tupperware Brands.

Leveraging this history at a time of heightened awareness among consumers about plastics pollution, also “gave us a fantastic opportunity to think about design, manufacturing, distribution, and consumption,” Gupta says. “This has to be inside and out.”

The No Time to Waste initiative is looking at everything from how Tupperware sources the raw materials it uses to how it can collect and then repurpose or recycle used products. Among its goals is “enhancing the return process,” for all Tupperware products, so that by 2025, 90% will be recycled and repurposed. It also aims to eliminate plastic packaging, boost its use of renewable energy, and reduce its water use.

Tupperware's Eco Straws Courtesy of Tupperware Brands Corp.

Among its initiatives is a partnership with the Ellen MacArthur Foundation’s New Plastic Economy, which is asking companies for a commitment to create a circular economy for plastic. To that end, Tupperware has a declared goal of “zero waste to landfill” by 2025.

One of the company’s first steps in this initiative is to make products out of a new “certified circular polymer” created from mixed plastic waste through a collaboration with the Saudi petrochemical company, SABIC, a supplier.

SABIC has designed a way to purify typical plastic waste products like shampoo or soda bottles to the molecular level, so that the resulting resin is food safe, Gupta says.

The first product made from this material that Tupperware plans to release to the market will be an “eco straw,” a sustainable alternative to plastic straws—the ubiquitous symbol of single-use plastics pollution.

Metal and paper substitutes for plastic straws haven’t been that good, so “we wanted to step in and provide a solution that was fantastic—it has great design, it’s amazing to use, and it’s made from sustainable sourced material,” Gupta says.

ITEM

While the Eco Straw and a coffee “to go” cup, also made from the new sustainable polymer, aren’t available to consumers just yet, Tupperware already offers several products designed to reduce food waste and cut energy use.

The company’s FridgeSmart Collection, for instance, is a line of containers designed by Tupperware in partnership with the University of Florida that has a venting system to control airflow and moisture. The venting allows the containers to extend the life of produce and preserve nutrients.

PRICE

A four-piece FridgeSmart set with two 1¾ quart small-deep containers, one gallon-deep container, and one 1¾ quart medium container costs $94 on Tupperware.com. Tupperware products are also available through the company’s three million global sales associates.

DESCRIPTION

FridgeSmart containers come in various sizes, and can be adjusted with a slide to match the air circulation requirements of specific produce. Like all Tupperware products, the containers have a limited lifetime warranty.

WHAT’S THE GOOD?

With more people shopping in bulk, and storing fruits and vegetables in the refrigerator, the FridgeSmart products (called VentSmart in some global markets) can prevent food waste, which is a major environmental problem, leading to lost energy and resources. (Up to 40% of the food in the United States is wasted, the National Resource Defense Council has found).

“The venting system allows for food to get the right amount of oxygen in the container, and that keeps it fresh,” Gupta says.

WHAT’S NEXT

Tupperware has several other products with a sustainable bent, including its Power Chef Premium System, which can process and chop vegetables, nuts, and herbs without electricity.

In Europe, the company has introduced a line of non-food-safe products made from recycled Tupperware, including outdoor watering cans. “We’re just starting to make sure that’s something we can start to cascade globally,” Gupta says.

One of its most innovative efforts is a partnership with a commercial space company, Techshot, to develop a system for growing fruits and vegetables in space for the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). Tupperware expects the technology in this product, called PONDS (Passive Orbital Nutrient Delivery System), can be adapted to future food waste products.
description: The 70-year-old direct seller is working to reduce—and eventually eliminate—its waste
